paragraphs.text: Children in our towns and cities are being robbed of safe spaces to play.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Where do the children play?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Where can they run around unsupervised?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On most of the housing estates I visit, the answer is hardly anywhere
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: A community not built around children is no community at all
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A place that functions socially is one in which they are drawn to play outdoors
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As Jay Griffiths argues in her heartrending book Kith, children fill the "unoccupied territories", the spaces not controlled by tidy-minded adults, "the commons of mud, moss, roots and grass"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: But such places are being purged from the land and their lives
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "Today's children are enclosed in school and home, enclosed in cars to shuttle between them, enclosed by fear, by surveillance and poverty and enclosed in rigid schedules of time."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Since the 1970s the area in which children roam without adults has decreased by almost 90%
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: "Childhood is losing its commons."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Given all
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that we know about the physical and psychological impacts of this confinement
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: you would expect the authorities to ensure that the remaining 10% of their diminished range is designed to draw children out of their homes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yet almost everywhere they are designed out
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Housing estates are built on the playing fields and rough patches children used to inhabit, and offer almost nothing in return
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the government's masterplan for England, the national planning policy framework, children are mentioned only twice: in a catalogue of housing types
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In parliament's review of these plans, they aren't mentioned at all
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Young people, around whom our lives should revolve, have been airbrushed from the planning system
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I spent Monday wandering around the new and newish housing developments on the east side of Northampton
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I chose this area because the estates here are spacious and mostly built for families
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: in other words, there is no possible excuse for excluding young people
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the places built 10 or 20 years ago, there is plenty of shared space
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: almost all of it is allocated to cars
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: (You can see the photos on my website
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Grass is confined to the roundabouts or to coffin-like gardens
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: in which you can't turn a cartwheel without hitting the fence
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I came across one exception - a street with wide grass verges
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But they sloped towards the road: dangerous and useless, a perfect waste of space
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: This land of missed opportunities, designed by people without a spark of joy in their hearts, reifies the idea that there is no such thing as society
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Had you set out to ensure that children were neither seen nor heard, you could not have done a better job
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On the last day of the holidays, which was warm and dry, across four estates I saw only one child
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: By comparison, the Cherry Orchard estate just completed by Bellway Homes is a children's paradise
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But only by comparison
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Next to the primary school, with plenty of three- and four-bedroom houses, it is designed to appeal to young families
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But in the middle of the development, where a village green might have been, there' s a strange grassy sump, surrounded by a low fence
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It's an empty balancing pond, to catch water during exceptional floods
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Remove the fence, plant it with trees, throw in some rocks and logs, and you'd have a rough and mossy playground
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But no such thing was in the plans
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Other shared spaces on the estate have the charming ambience of a prison yard
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: paved and surrounded by garden fences almost nine feet high
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: There were a few children outdoors
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they seemed pressed to the edges, sitting in doorways or leaning on fences
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Children don't buy houses
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: so who cares?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Throughout the country, they become prisoners of bad design, and so do adults
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Without safe and engaging places in which they can come together, no tribe forms
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So parents must play the games that children would otherwise play among themselves
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: everyone is bored to tears
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The exclusion of children arises from the same pathology that denies us decent housing
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the name of market freedom, the volume housebuilders, sitting on their land banks, are free to preside over speculative chaos
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: while we are free to buy dog kennels priced like palaces in placeless estates so badly designed that community is dead on arrival
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Many want to design and build their own homes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: almost no plots are available
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: as the big builders have seized them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In Scotland the government is considering compulsory sale orders
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which would pull down prices
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - essential when the speculative price of land has risen from 2% of the cost of a home in the 1930s to 70% today
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: A national housing land corporation would assemble the sites and supply the infrastructure, then sell plots to community groups, housing associations and people who want to build their own
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It goes far beyond England's feeble community right-to-build measures
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which lack the muscular facilitation that only public authorities can provide
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But it's still not far enough
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What if people were entitled to buy an option for a plot on a new estate, which they would then help to plan?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Not just the houses, but the entire estate would be built for and by those who would live there
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The council or land corporation would specify the number and type of homes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: then
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the future residents - including people on the social housing waiting list - would design the layout
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Their children would help to create the public spaces
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Communities would start to form
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: even before people moved in
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the estates would doubtless look nothing like those built today
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: To the Westminster government, this probably sounds like communism
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: as countries elsewhere in Europe have found, we don't need volume house builders, except to construct high-rises
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They do not assist the provision of decent, affordable homes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They impede it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What is good for them is bad for us
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Bellway, its brochure reveals, asked children at the neighbouring primary school to paint a picture of a cherry orchard, and displayed the winning entries in its show home
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "Why not pop over to say hello, view our wonderful development and sneak a peek?", it asks
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: That's the role the children were given: helping the company to sell the houses it had already built
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Why can't we shape the places that shape our lives?
paragraphs.label: assumption
